facts.text: The assessee is the appellant and is a private limited company carrying on the business of manufacture and sale of sugar.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, which is the appellant, is a private limited companypany carrying on the business of manufacture and sale of sugar.

facts.text: The assessee has two sugar mills: one at Maholi Sitapur and the other at Raja-ka-Sahaspur Moradabad.

anchor.surface_text: it has two sugar mills one at Maholi  Sitapur  and the other at Raja-ka-Sahaspur  Moradabad .

facts.text: The head office of the assessee is at New Delhi.

facts.text: During the accounting period relating to the assessment year 1956-57, the assessee paid sums of Rs. 75,000/- and Rs. 37,500/- to the Cane Development Council of the Sugarcane Department of the Government of Uttar Pradesh by way of contribution for road development between sugarcane producing centers and sugar factories.

anchor.surface_text: During the accounting period relating to the assessment year 1956-57 sums of Rs. 75,000/- and Rs. 37,500/- were paid by the assessee to the Cane Development Council of the Sugarcane Department of the Government of Uttar Pradesh by way of companytribution for road development between the various sugarcane producing centers and the sugar factories of the assessee.

facts.text: Revenue authorities held that the contributions constituted capital expenditure and could not be allowed as deduction.

anchor.surface_text: The revenue authorities found that these companytributions were intended to be applied for the companystruction and development of roads between the sugarcane producing centres and the sugar mills and held that these amounts companystituted capital expenditure and companyld number be allowed as an admissible deduction while companyputing the total income of the assessee.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal upheld the order of the departmental authorities.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal upheld the order of the departmental authorities.

facts.text: Tribunal referred two questions of law to the High Court on application.

anchor.surface_text: On an application being moved the Tribunal referred two questions of law to the High Court.

facts.text: The second question referred: Whether the sums of Rs. 75,000 and Rs. 37,500 paid to the Road Development Fund set up by the Government of U.P. were rightly disallowed as items of capital expenditure?

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned only, in the present case, with the second question which is as follows Whether the sums of Rs. 75,000 and Rs. 37,500 paid to the Road Development Fund set up by the Government of U.P. were rightly disallowed as items of capital expenditure ?

facts.text: Delhi High Court held that the expenditure could not be regarded as revenue expenditure and answered against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the aforesaid expenditure companyld number be regarded as revenue expenditure and the answer was returned against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The general principles governing the determination of the question whether an expenditure is in the nature of capital or revenue expenditure are well known. Where expenditure is incurred while the business is being carried on and number for its extension or for the substantial replacement of its equipment the position would be as follows - If the expenditure is made for acquiring or bringing into existence an asset or advantage for the enduring benefit of the business it is properly attributable to capital and is of the nature of capital expenditure. If on the other hand it is made number for the purpose of bringing into existence any such asset or advantage but for running the business or working it with a view to produce the profits it is a revenue expenditure.  Vide Assam Bengal Cement Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income tax, West Bengal 1

concepts.interpretation: Expenditure not for acquiring asset or enduring advantage but for running business is revenue; here roads not assessee's property, partial contribution, no enduring benefit found, for facilitating transport hence revenue

arguments.claim: General principles: expenditure for asset/enduring benefit is capital; for running business is revenue (citing Assam Bengal Cement)

anchor.surface_text: The general principles governing the determination of the question whether an expenditure is in the nature of capital or revenue expenditure are well known. Where expenditure is incurred while the business is being carried on and not for its extension or for the substantial replacement of its equipment the position would be as follows - If the expenditure is made for acquiring or bringing into existence an asset or advantage for the enduring benefit of the business it is properly attributable to capital and is of the nature of capital expenditure. If on the other hand it is made not for the purpose of bringing into existence any such asset or advantage but for running the business or working it with a view to produce the profits it is a revenue expenditure.  Vide Assam Bengal Cement Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income tax, West Bengal 1

arguments.claim: Expenditure is revenue as roads not assessee's property, not entire cost by assessee, to facilitate transport essential for sugarcane business

anchor.surface_text: In the present case apart from the element of compulsion the roads which were constructed and developed were not the, property of the assessee nor is it the case of the Revenue that the entire cost of development of those roads was defrayed by the assessee. It only made certain contribution for road development between the various cane producing centres and the mills. The apparent object and purpose was to facilitate the running of its motor vehicles or other means employed for transportation of sugarcane to the factory. From the business point of view and on a fair appreciation of the whole situation the assessee considered that the development of the road in question would greatly facilitate the transportation of sugarcane. This was essential for the benefit of its business which was of manufacturing sugar in which the main raw material admittedly consisted of sugarcane.

arguments.claim: Hindustan Motors analogous: contribution for government road improvement to ease transport difficulties is revenue

anchor.surface_text: The Calcutta High Court had occasion to consider an identical question in Commissioner of Income tax, West Bengal v. Hindustan Motors Ltd.  . There the location of a factory of motor car manufacturing company was a little distance away from the main road. The approach road belonged to the government. It fell into disrepair and began to cause transportation difficulties to the assessee. The Government was not prepared to meet the expenses for the repair of the road. The assessee offered to contribute a certain amount for the improvement. The High Court had no difficulty in coming to the conclusion that the money was spent not so much to bring about any asset or advantage of enduring benefit to itself but it was incurred for its efficient and convenient running and therefore it was of revenue nature.

arguments.claim: Royal Calcutta Turf Club analogous: expenditure for commercial expediency to train jockeys for business profitability is deductible revenue

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the ratio of the decision in Commissioner of Income tax, West Bengal, v. Royal Calcutta Turf Club 1  would be applicable to the present case. There the question was whether the expenditure on running a school for training of jockeys by the Royal Calcutta Turf Club could be claimed as a deduction under s. 10 (2) (xv) of the Indian Income tax Act 1922. It was pointed out that the business of the club was to run race meetings on a commercial scale for which it was necessary to have races of a high order. For the popularity of races and to make its business profitable it was necessary for the club to have jockeys of requisite skill and experience in sufficient numbers.

arguments.claim: Expenditure incurred for commercial expediency apart from statutory compulsion; roads development to facilitate business carrying on

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that in the present case the expenditure was incurred by the assessee for reasons of commercial expediency apart from statutory compulsion to which reference has been made before. The development of the roads was necessarily meant for facilitating the carrying on of the assessees business.

arguments.claim: Tribunal did not find roads were newly made or assessee gets enduring benefit

anchor.surface_text: Furthermore the Tribunal did not give any finding that the roads were to be altogether newly made and that the assessee would get an enduring benefit from these roads.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above the appeal is allowed and the answer given by the High Court to the question referred is discharged. We would return the answer in the negative and in favour of the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Expenditure for running business without acquiring asset or enduring benefit; roads not assessee's property, partial contribution only, facilitates sugarcane transport essential to sugar manufacturing business

holdings.text: Where expenditure is incurred while the business is being carried on and not for its extension or for the substantial replacement of its equipment the position would be as follows - If the expenditure is made for acquiring or bringing into existence an asset or advantage for the enduring benefit of the business it is properly attributable to capital and is of the nature of capital expenditure. If on the other hand it is made not for the purpose of bringing into existence any such asset or advantage but for running the business or working it with a view to produce the profits it is a revenue expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: The general principles governing the determination of the question whether an expenditure is in the nature of capital or revenue expenditure are well known. Where expenditure is incurred while the business is being carried on and not for its extension or for the substantial replacement of its equipment the position would be as follows - If the expenditure is made for acquiring or bringing into existence an asset or advantage for the enduring benefit of the business it is properly attributable to capital and is of the nature of capital expenditure.

holdings.text: These facts would bring it within the second part of the principle mentioned before, namely, that the expenditure was incurred for running the business or working it with a view to produce the profits without the assessee getting any advantage of an enduring benefit to itself.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the ratio of the decision in Commissioner of Income tax, West Bengal, v. Royal Calcutta Turf Club 1  would be applicable to the present case. There the question was whether the expenditure on running a school for training of jockeys by the Royal Calcutta Turf Club

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income tax, West Bengal v. Royal Calcutta Turf Club
precedents.cited_proposition: Expenditure incurred for commercial expediency to run the business profitably, such as training jockeys for high-quality races, is deductible.
precedents.cited_holding: Expenditure on running the school must be regarded as having been wholly and exclusively laid out for the purpose of the business of the club.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above the appeal is allowed and the answer given by the High Court to the question referred is discharged. We would return the answer in the negative and in favour of the assessee.

edges.explanation: Holding on expenditure for running business addresses issue on capital or revenue nature

anchor.surface_text: The general principles governing the determination of the question whether an expenditure is in the nature of capital or revenue expenditure are well known. Where expenditure is incurred while the business is being carried on and not for its extension or for the substantial replacement of its equipment the position would be as follows - If the expenditure is made for acquiring or bringing into existence an asset or advantage for the enduring benefit of the business it is properly attributable to capital and is of the nature of capital expenditure.

For the reasons given above the appeal is allowed and the answer given by the High Court to the question referred is discharged. We would return the answer in the negative and in favour of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case apart from the element of compulsion the roads which were constructed and developed were not the, property of the assessee nor is it the case of the Revenue that the entire cost of development of those roads was defrayed by the assessee. It only made certain contribution for road development between the various cane producing centres and the mills.

For the reasons given above the appeal is allowed and the answer given by the High Court to the question referred is discharged. We would return the answer in the negative and in favour of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that in the present case the expenditure was incurred by the assessee for reasons of commercial expediency apart from statutory compulsion to which reference has been made before. The development of the roads was necessarily meant for facilitating the carrying on of the assessees business.

For the reasons given above the appeal is allowed and the answer given by the High Court to the question referred is discharged. We would return the answer in the negative and in favour of the assessee.
